comments.body: Neat idea, tho you can already do this with datapacks. (/trigger, /function)

the only reason where its a bit wrong with the command syntax is that for example
/say has a infinite amount of arguments

so the command should be /createcommand <accessible by> <command>
just a flip of the arguments but it makes it easier to parse
while you can do this datapacks, some people aren't allowed to get datapacks.

Personally, I would like to have this kind of functionality because it's true that we would like to program a command for an entity and not always the server. I can even share an idea about it, such as keeping it so that by default, it's the server that executes, but if we specify in the command '/schedule function custom:function 1s append @s', it will be the person who executes the function.

I would also like functionalities like '/schedule clear custom:function @p', which would allow canceling the scheduled custom:function for the nearest player. If no player is specified, the server will be the target.

I hope this will be considered for a future update.
this would be very cool for map making or servers
Ooo i like this but maybe something like if it was minecraft:custom.blocking.holding.time making it so any item with the blocking property could be detected. Could be useful for any custom items.
and one for chraging a spear. like minecraft:custom.spear.charging.time

could work something like this
/gamerule mobGriefing true/false affects all mobGriefing rules

/gamerule mobGriefing <Specific mobGriefing rule> true/false only affects the specific mobGriefing rule mentioned in the command

I love this idea. It's super similar to my suggestion, too!
Would make teleporting to specific locations from different areas around a map easier

This has already been implemented in Java Edition by editing an armour stand's position to the target, then teleporting the player to the armour stand. Summon an armour stand with the tag tpHelp, then run the following commands:

scoreboard players set x tpCoordinates 12
scoreboard players set y tpCoordinates 23
scoreboard players set z tpCoordinates 34
execute store result entity @e[tag=tpHelp] Pos[0] run scoreboard players get x tpCoordinates
execute store result entity @e[tag=tpHelp] Pos[1] run scoreboard players get y tpCoordinates
execute store result entity @e[tag=tpHelp] Pos[2] run scoreboard players get z tpCoordinates
/teleport @p @e[tag=tpHelp]

I think it would be better if we could just insert any data from the scoreboard using (scoreboard name). For example: / tp @s ~ ~(dypos) ~ or just /tp @s (posx) (posy) (poz).

Edit:
I mean to put into the command whatever we want.

It would be also great to do any math with it, but I think it is not necessary.

I don't think that it should be completely detatched from the difficulty, I think that when you set the difficulty it should change if the gamerule is true or false, and if you want to change the difficulty but you want doHunger to stay the same you could set difficultyChangesHunger to false (if someone else can come up with a better name use that). Why is because it would be confusing for people that don't keep up with the updates, also because it would be easier, and because in Java you can't change gamerules when you're creating the world (or maybe you can I'm not sure, I play Bedrock).

sudo is used in UNIX to execute commands as a superuser (sudo = superuser do). I don't see why it would behave the way you describe it.

sudo, if anything, should execute the command as an op (server operator, as that would be the equivalent of a superuser). But it would be redundant, since you already are an op, if you're able to use that command.

 

While I can see the point of having a command the way you describe it, sudo is not the right name

You can already do this using the /execute as command:

/execute as @a[name=!YOURNAME] run say Hi
You can use execute. /execute as @e run say hello

(Reply to Hori873)

I may be wrong but I am pretty sure there are server plugins that do exactly this with the /sudo command. I don't know why the name "sudo" was chosen in the first place but I think that's why OP said that.

1. Hori873 is correct, if you wanted a pseudonym then use something like /pseudo

2. the point of making the name in /say different to just typing in chat is to prevent stuff like this

3. this can still be done with careful usage of /tellraw, as so

/execute as PlayerYouWantToImpersonate run tellraw @a ["",{"text":"<"},{"selector":"@s","hoverEvent":{"action":"show_entity","value":"@s"}},{"text":"> Your Message"}]

(you can even pseudo as entities as well)

I know, it's been a long time, but I want to say, that sudo in Unix doesn't mean "Superuser Do" it means "Switch User Do" and the default user to switch to is root. Therefore, the name makes perfect sense, it switches user and executes commands.
/execute as @a say Hi
